results.title: Measure metric: length 2: a thousand clicks
results.brief_description: Demonstrates how to measure circular objects and record the answers using decimal notation, how to measure lengths that are more than one metre, and how to use the trundle wheel to measure a kilometre. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Measure metric: length 1: who measures?
results.brief_description: Two teenage boys explore metric measurement in downtown Toronto. Demonstrates proper length-measuring technqiues, using the appropriate measurement instrument, and learning the linea equivalents of 1m, 10cm, 1000cm. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: If you're a horse
results.creator_credit: William Van Horn, Paul B. Foster, Davidson Films and Xerox Publication Films
results.brief_description: Part of the “Human values series”. This episode shows what happens when a horse that loves to eat apples meets an ogre that loves to eat horses. Encourages examination of the idea of temptation in human values. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Food and growth
results.brief_description: Explains the functions of the mouth, stomach and intestine in the digestion of food. Shows how food is carried by the circulatory system to the cells, allowing cell division and growth. Suitable for upper primary and lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: The Beats go on: percussion from Pleistocene to Paradiddle
results.creator_credit: Lee Mishkin, Nick Bosustow, Stephen Bosustow Productions and Xerox Films
results.brief_description: Traces the existence of percussion instruments throughout man’s history, examining both development and playing techniques. Considers the types of idiophones which make a sound when they are hit, shaken or struck. Features drummer, Shelly Manne. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Lee Mishkin, Nick Bosustow, Stephen Bosustow Productions and Xerox Films

results.title: Plow that broke the plains
results.creator_credit: Pare Lorentz and United States. Resettlement Administration
results.brief_description: Depicts the ecological and human disaster that occured in America’s southwestern Great Plains region during the 1930s. The ‘Dust Bowl’ resulted from poor agricultural practices and sustained drought and is considered to have prolonged the depression. Lorentz recruited Paul Strand, Ralph Steiner and Leo Hurwitz to photograph the devastation. Their haunting images, combined with Virgil Thomson’s original film ballad and narration by Thomas Chalmers capture the tragedy that forced thousands of farmers to leave their land. Founded in 1935 as part of Roosevelt’s New Deal, the Resettlement Administration aimed to relocate impoverished farming families and poor city families. Written by Pare Lorentz.
